Try the burgers at Quad Grill. $8 for a decent Wagyu patty with amazing additions. Also, Green Papaya is the best Viet on campus in Mathews Pavilion - the salad noodle, soup and pork buns are great. The Asian place across subway is also really good. Try their wonton noodles or their Hainan Chicken. Stellini pasta near the IGA is also a fan favourite and the curry in Mathews is quite good with really nice garlic naan.

Absolutely. There are quite a few Chinese, but in the streets and living here I'd say there's a huge variety of people of all cultures. But I really do appreciate the abundance of Chinese people here - there is actually night life (and that Westfield stays open fairly late, winning!). Give it a year or two and the place will be utterly gentrified. Parramatta will be going that way too. Sad thing is that most apartments here sit empty. I don't have neighbours on my floor for example. But I would love to buy into this place before the prices go beyond 700K. I just love the culture here. Another good place is Croydon followed by Concord. And if you don't mind the interesting transport Rhodes and Wentworth Point too.

I'd argue it has far more reliable transport than the eastern suburbs and North Sydney where I grew up.
The CBD is a poorly designed mess of buildings and the inner west where it can expand to is mostly residential, making it near impossible. Hubs which can and will be well planned like Parramatta and Bella Vista are our best hope of moving or putting high paying jobs elsewhere. Microsoft in Washington isn't in Seattle, it's in a city outside of Seattle called Redmond. Facebook headquarters isn't in San Francisco, it's in a smaller city more than an hour away from the CBD. And this all works.

The west is the future. The east and inner west is just pots of investment properties and gentrification. And I'm saying this as someone living in the inner west who works in the city. I can't wait until I can move to the west and start my own practice

Cheap? Far from it. Our CBD needs to expand. Parramatta is one small step in the right direction. Next should be further west in the Hills District and south towards Cambelltown and Glenfield. That's where people can afford housing, that's where jobs need to go - where the people are. Not the other way around. We have seen for the past decade that this isn't working.

La Perouse - lots of beach and rock pools to explore with a surprising lack of people. When I lived in Coogee, I would take the bus here to hang out with my dog and just relax and find small crabs. There's also a lighthouse which opens for tours.
Burwood Park - lots of cute ducks and the park is very organised and large enough for you to find a nook to stay. I think there is also council wifi here (or at least there is near the Oliver Brown).
State Library and the park near the Art Gallery of NSW.

Literally declare everything. I even declare my medications. I've brought into the country so many snacks and foods from Thailand and Japan. Never had anything taken from me. Just a "Is it in a sealed container? Sweet. Come on through!" Half the time they don't even bother opening it up to check. If you declare, you'll have an easier time and most likely be able to bring in food items you wouldn't be able to otherwise.

Um no. This has never happened to me. Although I have seen it in patients, particularly those who have had strokes (they'll bite the side of their tongue they no longer feel). You may been sucking too hard. You don't want to feel like your soft palate is about to be sucked out of position. If you have any little white spots, get an antiseptic oral ulcer gel. It helps ward off bacteria and provides a barrier against food and abrasive motions so you'll heal up faster. As for the bruising, some ice to bring down any swelling and avoid hot foods.

The government actually decided to do it. There is a unit called TARS which is basically a research unit for transport and road safety based on UNSW who conduct research to assess whether these safety decisions are even viable or useful before they launch completely and millions are spent. You might actually be surprised at the results. I am too. I honestly had no hope for it at the beginning but hey, choice architecture works.
I'm actually a part of this project. What you see is an experimental trial, not a final product.

An antiseptic and numbing lozenge should do the trick. I believe Strepsils makes one. Be warned though, some people find the numbing agent to produce a laxative effect.
Alternatively, drinking warm honey and lemon tea is rather soothing and a warm salt water wash is mildly antiseptic. You can also take malt drops. I'd advise against alcohol because it could make an infection (if there is one) sting and not necessarily get better. If symptoms persist, get it looked at for strep.

You have yellow toned skin and facial redness. Adding a cool or pink foundation will only make the redness worse. Use a green primer on the red parts of your face and neck, and then apply a yellow toned or neutral foundation. :)

Because people forget that hair can be dyed. Sailor Moon and most other manga, video game and anime characters have features that look white like eye and hair colour, because the technology and design limitations made it hard to differentiate between characters. Whether Sailor Moon is of Japanese heritage is a different argument because it's never discussed, but I'm fairly certain a series made for a Japanese audience consciously created a non-Japanese ethnic main character. She's just Sailor Moon. Matoko from Ghost in the Shell however is a more complicated concept which is deeply explored in the series. She's explicitly Japanese. Interpreting her as otherwise is stupid

If you are having unprotected sex regularly, it's recommended to get tested once a month. Getting tested more often could only lead to false negatives. If you are having regular protected sex, then it's every 6 months. However, if you feel you need to get tested or should, then certainly do get tested. It's not so much a matter of picking up the STIs you caught from your most recent hook up, but also from hook ups weeks or months before.

Hello, Husband.

I can't really say much except, do what feels right to you. I got married at 18. Almost 6 years later and we are still good and strong, if not stronger than we were all those years ago. We can throw stats and anecdotes around, but at the end of the day, we aren't in your relationship and we cannot truly judge.
A lot can also happen after you get married and you have to know, deep within whether or not you can deal with it. My husband was injured on deployment and he had to use a wheelchair for the majority of 2 years. Not to mention the PTSD, ensuing financial troubles and having to work 3(!!!) jobs whilst attending university full-time. If someone asked me if I would be determined to face that and be with him if I marry him, I can guarantee I'd say no, lol. But the fact is, that I stuck it out and would much rather go through all that again if it means I have the amazing man who is my husband.
So yeah. Do as you please. We can't predict the future - good or bad - but you can decide on which options are available to you and which ones sound better.

So....I was born in Russia.
Prior to Putin, Russia was becoming more progressive since a little before the downfall of the Soviet Union. There were plenty of gay bars, drag culture, my parents were very progressive as was my grandmother (still are) and I even have a gay uncle. A lot of musicians were actively appealing to a queer audience, and even implemented aspects of queer culture. Ruki Vverh and Tatu for example. It's just sad what the country has become by giving anti-gay people a voice, a platform and power. Interestingly enough, queer celebrities are well loved and so is camp and men dressing up as women. The government, and thus the media, censors the well-known fact that these people are gay, or their flamboyance and style is actually a display of queerness. They just want to enjoy it and pretend it can still be a straight thing so they don't feel too sinful *eyeroll*

Angkor is lovely, but probably not feasible in the little time you have. Checking in and out of hotels eats up a lot of your time since check out is usually before noon and check in is 2pm. So half your day is gone waiting to get your bags in your room, unless you want to pay extra for storage. If you had 7 days, that would be great.
When I did my Asia trip, I used Expedia religiously. Agoda was a mess and having talked to a few independent hoteliers, not only does the site mess up their details, but also payments take a long time to get to them, the commission fee is huge and they sometimes don't get info on their end for days at a time. So use Expedia. It was the only one people were actually organised with dealing with.
Also, there aren't that many flights going direct to Cambodia. They usually stop at Bangkok or KL. So you might be better off going to Thailand and seeing Wat Arun, Wat Phra Kaew or going to Ayutthaya.

*cracks speech pathologist knuckles*
Well this certainly brings me back. The phenomenon you are experiencing is called 'convergence' it is a form of social code switching where when you talk to a specific social group you adjust the way you speak so that it suits the social group and makes you sound similar to members of the group. People with migrant parents know this really well - when they talk to their parents they usually speak with an accent, but don't when speaking to friends who don't share that ethnic background.
You can read more [here](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communication_accommodation_theory). This wiki is surprisingly in depth and accurate.
Did you study linguistics too and hate syntax?

It depends on how you look at it and how much being gay has impacted your life. Being gay is a part of who I am - it explains why I had been discriminated in my past, why I can still continue to be discriminated and why people don't treat my relationship seriously. It's a part of my identity because people have used it to give me certain life experiences which have impacted me in such a way to shape who I am. But does it mean I identify with the scene? No. But I'd be lying to say that being gay hasn't in some way shaped my personality, just like my racial identity - it's something that put me in a certain social position and I've had to adapt in ways straight people don't have to.
